Association. ZIEGLER: In the course of your term as Chairman of the Staff Association, how did you go about trying to mobilize staff support, which is, of course, always a very crucial ingredient in the success, or lack thereof, of the Staff Association?

At the time when we took office in mid-1986, all available objective indicators of membership seemed to indicate there had been quite a weakening of staff support for the Association. Iâ€™m not quite clear over what period this occurred, nor am I clear exactly why this happened. We were never able to establish as good a database on the past membership trends as we would have liked, although we did get our membership database overhauled and up to snuff with help from David Delmonte during the year. One of the ways, if you recall, was that we launched a membership campaign that went on during the year. Godwin Agodo was one of the leading lights and most active people involved in this. doc.abstracts: In January 1989 Christopher Redfern was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Charles Ziegler. During his tenure at the bank from 1978 to 1989, Mr. Redfern served on the executive committee and as chairman of the staff association (1986-1987). He became a delegate for the West Africa region in 1984. In collaboration with the World Bank Group Staff Association, this interviewee was significantly involved in the Staff Association. The interview concerns only involvement in the Association and not the World Bank Group.
